abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as fully
            satisfactory. However, the quality of road works could have
            been higher if international technical supervision standards
            had been in place. Also, it would have been better if the
            government had developed more adequate road user charges to
            assure the necessary level of funding for road maintenance
            beyond emergency repairs and reconstruction. Other lessons
            learned: The risk of currency fluctuations needs to be
            considered when calculating contingencies and determining
            credit amounts. State control procedures need to be adapted
            to internationally accepted and recognized methods,
            including official acceptance of the reports of the
            international auditors provided under the Development Credit
            Agreement. Initially, there were response delays and
            misunderstandings on procurement matters because of
            inexperience and lack of project ownership in the Georgian
            transport sector; however, project ownership increased
            during implementation. There were difficulties in editing
            Georgian translations of reports prepared by foreign
            consultants in English and translated by local interpreters.
            The latter need to have some background in analytical skills
            to understand the subject and good knowledge of Georgian
            technical language. Georgian translations of concepts and
            terms used by the Bank in legal documents and procedures
            need unifying. Other fields needing to exchange information
            and to increase cooperation are procurement, accounting, and training.

18153200.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Rehabilitation Project,
            which is the first transport sector investment project in
            Georgia, has the following objectives: 1) to support policy
            reform in the transport sector and restructure its
            institutions to operate in a market economy; and 2) to
            repair and maintain some of the most critical elements of
            the transport system. The project has two main components:
            a) an institution building component, which includes policy
            reform, support to the transport reform and rehabilitation
            center, and consultant services to modal agencies and
            operational units; and b) an investment component comprising
            a road maintenance program and a railway sub-component.
